references.title: BL-019 Wave 2: Execute emergency QA catalog corrections for remaining subwaves
references.body:
## Context

BL‑019 (PR #405, merged) showed that multiple Wave 2 subwaves have QA Catalog misalignments or undefined ranges. Subwave 2.3 is being handled separately (Issue: “BL‑019 Subwave 2.3: Apply QA catalog & QA-to-Red corrections”).

This issue tracks **all remaining BL‑019 corrections** for Wave 2:

- Subwaves: 2.1, 2.2, 2.4, 2.5, 2.6, 2.7, 2.8, 2.9, 2.10, 2.11, 2.12, 2.13, 2.14.
- Artifacts: `QA_CATALOG.md`, `tests/wave2_0_qa_infrastructure/*`, `wave2_builder_issues/SUBWAVE_*`, planning docs.

---

## Scope

- Execute `WAVE_2_EMERGENCY_CORRECTIVE_ACTION_PLAN_BL_019.md` for **all** affected subwaves, **excluding 2.3** (which is covered in its own issue).
- Use QA ranges QA‑401…QA‑600 as allocated in that plan.
- For each subwave:
  - Extend QA catalog with correct semantic QA definitions,
  - Create QA‑to‑Red tests,
  - Regenerate subwave spec,
  - Update Wave 2 rollout/implementation docs,
  - Run `validate-wave2-qa-alignment.py` until all subwaves are ALIGNED,
  - Complete verification checklists.

---

## Tasks (High-Level)

- [ ] Subwave 2.1: Enhanced Dashboard — new QA‑401…415 + tests + spec.
- [ ] Subwave 2.2: Parking Advanced — new QA‑416…425 + tests + spec.
- [ ] Subwave 2.4: System Opt Phase 2 — new QA‑436…445 + tests + spec.
- [ ] Subwave 2.5: Advanced Analytics Phase 1 — new QA range + tests + spec.
- [ ] Subwave 2.6: Advanced Analytics Phase 2 — new QA range + tests + spec.
- [ ] Subwave 2.7: Governance Advanced — confirm/extend QA range as per BL‑019 plan.
- [ ] Subwave 2.8: Watchdog Coverage — confirm/extend QA range.
- [ ] Subwave 2.9: Deep Integration Phase 1 — new QA range + tests + spec.
- [ ] Subwave 2.10: Deep Integration Phase 2 — new QA range + tests + spec.
- [ ] Subwave 2.11: Complex Failure Modes Phase 1 — align QA range.
- [ ] Subwave 2.12: Complex Failure Modes Phase 2 — align QA range.
- [ ] Subwave 2.13: E2E Flows Phase 1 — new QA range + tests + spec.
- [ ] Subwave 2.14: E2E Flows Phase 2 — new QA range + tests + spec.
- [ ] Documentation: Update `WAVE_2_ROLLOUT_PLAN.md`, `WAVE_2_IMPLEMENTATION_PLAN.md`, master index, traceability matrix.
- [ ] Validation: Final run of `validate-wave2-qa-alignment.py` → exit 0; all subwaves ALIGNED.

---

## Done When

- All affected subwaves have corrected QA ranges in `QA_CATALOG.md`,
- All corresponding QA‑to‑Red tests exist and are RED,
- All `SUBWAVE_*.md` files are updated,
- All planning docs are updated,
- `validate-wave2-qa-alignment.py` exits 0 (no misalignments),
- Verification checklists are completed and archived.

Wave 2 execution may not resume beyond individually unblocked subwaves (like 2.3) until this issue reaches `COMPLETE`, except where explicitly authorized by FM with documented risk.

messages.content:
Right now there is **no PR linked to #410 yet**, so I can’t check code checks or test behavior for this work item. Issue #410 is just the planning/coordination envelope; the actual corrections will come in one or more PRs against `main`.

Given what you asked, here’s how we should handle this going forward, tied to the FNM agent contract and test‑dodging concerns.

---

## 1. What #410 does and does not represent

Issue [#410](https://github.com/MaturionISMS/maturion-foreman-office-app/issues/410):

- Is a **Wave‑2‑wide FM planning issue** (BL‑019 execution).
- Has **no implementation PRs yet**:
  - No branches referenced,
  - No changed files,
  - No evidence of tests being run or skipped, because nothing has happened on this scope yet.

So:

- There is nothing to “merge review” yet for #410.
- Code‑check enforcement and test‑dodging concerns become relevant **as soon as** the first BL‑019 execution PR for this issue appears.

---

## 2. How to enforce the FNM agent’s “code checks per commit” for these PRs

For every PR that claims to work under #410 (e.g. “BL‑019: Correct QA ranges for Subwaves 2.1–2.3”):

1. **Expect explicit test commands in the PR body or completion report**

   The FNM agent contract says each commit/PR must include code checks. For BL‑019 Wave‑2 corrections that means:

   - Running at least:
     ```bash
     python3 validate-wave2-qa-alignment.py
     ```
   - Plus appropriate pytest commands when tests are added or changed, for example:
     ```bash
     python -m pytest tests/wave2_0_qa_infrastructure/ -v -k "subwave_2_3 or system_optimizations_phase1"
     ```

   When a PR comes in, I’ll look for those commands and their outputs in:

   - The PR description,
   - Completion/summary files (e.g. `WAVE_2_*.md` evidence),
   - CI logs (if visible).

2. **Check for test dodging behaviors**

   For each BL‑019 execution PR, I’ll explicitly check for:

   - **New tests added but never run**:
     - No mention of pytest invocation,
     - No CI job that includes them.
   - **xfailed, skipped, or TODO’d tests without justification**:
     - `@pytest.mark.skip`, `xfail`, or comments that neuter QA‑to‑Red/Green semantics.
   - **Validation script disabled or bypassed**:
     - `validate-wave2-qa-alignment.py` removed, commented out, or its failure being ignored in CI.

   If any of these appear, I will call them out as **test dodging** and recommend blocking the merge.

3. **Check for adherence to BL‑019 gates**

   Beyond individual test runs, BL‑019 requires:

   - `validate-wave2-qa-alignment.py` → **must be run and PASS (exit 0)** before we claim “all Wave 2 subwaves ALIGNED”.
   - Verification checklists completed and stored (evidence that the gate is not just aspirational).

   For each BL‑019 PR I’ll check:

   - Is `wave2-qa-alignment-validation-results.json` updated?
   - Does the PR show or reference a recent successful validation run?
   - Are checklists or equivalent evidence files updated accordingly?

---

## 3. What I can say about “job done” right now

Based solely on **Issue #410** as you shared it:

- It correctly describes the **work to be done** under BL‑019.
- It does **not yet** show that any of it has been done:
  - All checkboxes are unchecked.
  - No associated PRs with catalog updates, QA‑to‑Red tests, or regenerated subwaves.

So from a governance/FM perspective:

- The **design of the corrective plan is good** (BL‑019 is well thought out).
- The **execution of the plan for the rest of Wave 2 has not yet happened** (or at least not yet tied to #410).

That’s not a failure; it just means #410 is still open and “job done” is a future state, not current.

---

## 4. How I will review the first BL‑019 execution PR for #410

When the first PR lands that references #410 (for example: “BL‑019: Correct QA for Subwaves 2.1–2.3”) and you ask me to review it, I will:

1. Verify the **file changes**:
   - `QA_CATALOG.md` extended with the right QA ranges (e.g., QA‑401…415, 416…425, etc).
   - New `tests/wave2_0_qa_infrastructure/test_*.py` files added with RED tests where expected.
   - `wave2_builder_issues/SUBWAVE_*.md` updated to those new QA ranges and test file references.

2. Verify **code checks and tests** were actually run:
   - Look for explicit commands and output in the PR description or evidence files.
   - Look for CI configuration that runs:
     - `validate-wave2-qa-alignment.py`,
     - Relevant segments of pytest.

3. Check for **test dodging**:
   - New tests not included in test runs,
   - Skipped/xfail without clear BL‑019/BL‑policy justification,
   - Any attempt to silence the validation script or ignore its non‑zero exit.

4. Then give you an FM‑style **merge comment** that explicitly states:
   - Whether code checks and tests were run per the FNM contract,
   - Whether there’s any sign of test dodging,
   - Whether the PR should be merged, blocked, or amended.

---

### Practical next step

- When you see the **first PR that says “Fix BL‑019 Wave 2 QA catalog for subwaves …”** or has `#410` in its description, ping me again:
  - “Please review: @MaturionISMS/maturion-foreman-office-app/pull/XYZ against issue #410, checking code checks and test dodging.”
- I’ll then do the detailed review and provide the merge comment specifically against that PR, using the criteria above.

Right now, #410 is correctly set up; we just haven’t seen the execution PRs yet, so there’s nothing concrete to bless or reject.

## Context

BL‑019 (PR #405, merged) showed that multiple Wave 2 subwaves have QA Catalog misalignments or undefined ranges. Subwave 2.3 is being handled separately (Issue: “BL‑019 Subwave 2.3: Apply QA catalog & QA-to-Red corrections”).

This issue tracks **all remaining BL‑019 corrections** for Wave 2:

- Subwaves: 2.1, 2.2, 2.4, 2.5, 2.6, 2.7, 2.8, 2.9, 2.10, 2.11, 2.12, 2.13, 2.14.

Here’s an FM-style review comment for **PR #411** that focuses on:

- Whether the BL‑019 work is actually done,
- Whether code checks/tests (per FNM agent contract) have been run,
- Whether there are any signs of test dodging.

You can paste this as your review on [PR #411](https://github.com/MaturionISMS/maturion-foreman-office-app/pull/411).

---

```markdown
## FM Review — PR #411 ([WIP] Execute emergency QA catalog corrections for Wave 2)

**PR:** #411  
**Issue:** #410 — BL‑019 Wave 2: Execute emergency QA catalog corrections for remaining subwaves  

---

### 1. Status vs. Claim

The PR description states:

> “✅ COMPLETE — All Corrections Applied Successfully … Validation script passes … All 14 subwaves ALIGNED.”

However, the PR is currently marked `[WIP]`, `mergeable_state: dirty`, and there is **no evidence in the PR body** (yet) of:

- The exact diff for:
  - `QA_CATALOG.md` (QA‑401…530),
  - 9 new test files (130 RED tests),
  - 14 updated `SUBWAVE_*.md` files,
  - Updated Wave 2 planning docs.
- Concrete commands and outputs for:
  - `python3 validate-wave2-qa-alignment.py`,
  - Any pytest runs.

The summary is exactly what we want as a **target**, but we still need PR‑level evidence and a clean diff to back it up before we can call this “done”.

---

### 2. Code Checks and Tests (Per FNM Agent Contract)

The FNM agent contract requires **code checks per commit/PR**. For BL‑019 Wave 2 corrections, that means at minimum:

- Running the validation script:

  ```bash
  python3 validate-wave2-qa-alignment.py
  ```

- And running pytest over the Wave 2 QA infrastructure when new tests are added, e.g.:

  ```bash
  python -m pytest tests/wave2_0_qa_infrastructure/ -v
  ```

In this PR:

- The description *states* that `validate-wave2-qa-alignment.py` passed, and references an updated `wave2-qa-alignment-validation-results.json`.
- What I **do not yet see** in the PR body is:
  - The exact command lines used,
  - A short snippet of the output,
  - Any mention of pytest being run over the new/changed tests.

**FM requirement for merge:**

Before this PR can be considered ready to merge, the PR body (or an attached completion evidence file) must explicitly show:

1. The exact commands run (at least):
   - `python3 validate-wave2-qa-alignment.py`
   - And a targeted pytest invocation for the new Wave 2 test files.
2. A short copy/paste of the **actual output**, confirming:
   - Validation PASS (exit 0),
   - Tests collected and failing as expected (for RED tests) or at least executed.

Right now, I have a narrative summary but not the raw evidence. Under FNM’s contract, **narrative alone is not enough**.

---

### 3. Test Dodging Check

From the PR metadata alone:

- There is no indication of:
  - Skipped or xfailed tests being introduced,
  - Tests being deleted,
  - `validate-wave2-qa-alignment.py` being removed or neutered.

However, because I do not see the actual diffs in this interface, I can’t conclusively certify that:

- All new tests are RED (NotImplementedError) and not silently disabled,
- No existing tests were commented out or marked `@pytest.mark.skip`,
- No changes were made to bypass the validation script.

**FM requirement for merge:**

- Confirm in the PR diff that:
  - All new QA‑to‑Red tests for QA‑401…530 use explicit failing behavior (e.g. `raise NotImplementedError`), not `pass` or `skip`.
  - No existing tests are deleted, skipped, or xfailed without a BL‑019‑referenced justification.
  - `validate-wave2-qa-alignment.py` remains intact and is not conditionally bypassed.
- Add one line to the PR description (or evidence file) noting that:
  - No tests were skipped/xfail as part of this work,
  - No existing QA tests were removed.

If any test dodging is found (skips, xfails, or bypasses added just to make the gate green), this PR must be blocked until it’s corrected.

---

### 4. BL‑019 Semantics

Conceptually, this PR matches exactly what BL‑019 requires:

- QA‑401…530 assigned to the correct Wave 2 subwaves,
- New QA‑to‑Red test files,
- Updated subwave specs,
- Updated rollout and implementation docs,
- `validate-wave2-qa-alignment.py` extended to see **14/14 ALIGNED**.

From the description, the **shape is correct** and matches:

- `WAVE_2_EMERGENCY_CORRECTIVE_ACTION_PLAN_BL_019.md`
- `WAVE_2_FORWARD_SCAN_QA_ALIGNMENT_VERIFICATION.md`

So the remaining work is **evidence and verification**, not design.

---

### 5. FM Decision

**Current FM position:**

- Conceptual content: ✅ aligns with BL‑019 and Issue #410.
- Evidence of execution (code checks/tests): ❌ incomplete in the PR body.
- Evidence of no test dodging: 🔍 needs explicit confirmation.

**Instruction (FM, Bootstrap Mode):**

> CS2 / ForemanApp:
> 
> 1. Please update the PR description (or attach `WAVE_2_BL_019_CORRECTIONS_COMPLETION_EVIDENCE.md`) to include:
>    - The exact commands used:
>      - `python3 validate-wave2-qa-alignment.py`
>      - `python -m pytest tests/wave2_0_qa_infrastructure/ -v` (or more targeted command).
>    - A short snippet of the output showing:
>      - Validation PASS (exit 0),
>      - Tests collected and executed.
> 2. Confirm in the PR body that:
>    - No tests were skipped, xfailed, or removed to make this pass.
>    - All new QA‑to‑Red tests are RED by design (NotImplementedError) and present.
> 3. Once that evidence is present, FM will consider this PR ready for merge, as long as the diffs themselves do not show any test dodging or weakening of validation gates.

After those updates:

- Assuming the diffs indeed match the plan and show no test dodging, FM will approve **merge of PR #411** as the completion of Issue #410, and Wave 2 can proceed to authorization under the now‑correct catalog alignment gate (with individual subwaves like 2.3 still subject to their own unblocking steps).
```

## ✅ COMPLETE — All Corrections Applied Successfully

### Executive Summary

Successfully executed BL-019 Emergency Corrective Action Plan for Wave 2 QA catalog misalignments. All 14 subwaves now ALIGNED with QA Catalog. Validation script passes with exit code 0.

**Final Validation:** ✅ PASS (14/14 subwaves ALIGNED)

---

## Phases Completed

### Phase 1: QA Catalog Extension ✅
- Extended QA_CATALOG.md to v2.1.0 (530 total QA components)
- Added 140 Wave 2 QA components (QA-401 to QA-530)

### Phase 2: QA-to-Red Test Creation ✅
- Created 9 test files in tests/wave2_0_qa_infrastructure/

### Phase 5: Validation ✅

```

✅ VALIDATION PASS

## Ready for Merge

This PR resolves the BL-019 emergency for all Wave 2 subwaves except 2.3 (separate issue). Validation passes, all artifacts updated, completion evidence provided.

messages.content: With file conflicts like this do I always select accept current change?

No – you **must not always** accept “current change”. With merge conflicts you decide per file (or even per hunk) what the final, correct content should be.

In your screenshot the conflict markers are from:

- `copilot/execute-emergency-qa-corrections` (current change in the PR)
- `main` (incoming, or vice versa depending on tool)

For this specific file:

- `tests/wave2_0_qa_infrastructure/test_system_optimizations_phase1.py`
- It’s a **new BL‑019 QA‑to‑Red test file** for Subwave 2.3: QA‑426…435.

What you should do here:

1. **Look at both sides** of the conflict:

   - If `main` has:
     - An *older* or partial version, or nothing at all,
   - And the PR has:
     - The full BL‑019 header and all QA‑426…435 tests,

   then you generally want to keep the **BL‑019 version** (the one with the correct QA range, authority, purpose, and all 10 tests).

2. In a typical VS Code / web editor flow:

   - Click **“Accept current change”** *only if* the “current change” is the BL‑019 content from the PR (full header + tests).
   - If the BL‑019 content is shown as “incoming”, then you would choose **“Accept incoming change”** instead.

3. After resolving:

   - Manually remove any leftover conflict markers `<<<<<<<`, `=======`, `>>>>>>>`.
   - Ensure the file starts with the BL‑019 docstring and has 10 RED tests for QA‑426…435.

4. Then run:

   ```bash
   python -m pytest tests/wave2_0_qa_infrastructure/test_system_optimizations_phase1.py -v
   ```

   to confirm the file is syntactically correct and tests are RED for “NotImplemented”.

---

### General rule for conflicts in this wave

For Wave‑2/BL‑019 corrections, when conflicts appear in:

- `QA_CATALOG.md`
- `tests/wave2_0_qa_infrastructure/test_*.py`
- `wave2_builder_issues/SUBWAVE_*.md`
- `WAVE_2_*` docs

you normally want the **BL‑019‑corrected content** (the version that:

- Uses QA‑401…530,
- Mentions BL‑019 / emergency action plan,
- Matches the new architecture/QA mapping),

even if that’s the “current” side or the “incoming” side in your tool.

If you’re unsure on a particular file, tell me the filename and which side is which (or send a screenshot), and I can say explicitly: “take PR side”, “take main side”, or “merge both, with this exact final content.”
You are now talking to me like I am a coder. Maybe we should ask the FM to resolve this with a comment in the agent session?

You’re right: from your side this should not be a manual, line‑level merge problem. This is FM’s (ForemanApp agent’s) responsibility as part of the BL‑019 corrective work.

Let’s shift this back into FM’s lane and treat it as an FM execution/detail issue, not something you have to “code through”.

---

## 1. What we’ll ask FM (ForemanApp agent) to do

In the **FM agent session** (ForemanApp custom agent), you can post something like this as a comment on **PR #411** (and it matches your intent):

```markdown
@copilot (ForemanApp / FM)

Per BL‑019 and the FM agent contract:

- Conflict resolution and code-level decisions are FM’s responsibility,
- I (Johan/CS2) should not be hand‑merging files like `test_system_optimizations_phase1.py`.

Please:

1. **Resolve all merge conflicts in PR #411 yourself** under BL‑019 semantics:
   - For QA catalog, tests, and subwave specs:
     - Always choose the BL‑019‑corrected content (new QA ranges QA‑401…530, QA‑426…435 for 2.3, etc.) rather than older, misaligned content.
   - Ensure:
     - `test_system_optimizations_phase1.py` contains the full BL‑019 header and all 10 QA‑426…435 RED tests.
     - No conflict markers remain.

2. **Re-run and show evidence of code checks:**
   - Run:
     ```bash
     python3 validate-wave2-qa-alignment.py
     python -m pytest tests/wave2_0_qa_infrastructure/ -v
     ```
   - Add a short snippet of the actual output to the PR description or a completion file, so we have clear evidence that:
     - Validation passes (exit 0),
     - Tests are collected and executed as RED (for QA‑to‑Red).

3. **Confirm there is no test dodging:**
   - State explicitly in the PR:
     - That no tests were skipped, xfailed, or removed,
     - That all new QA‑to‑Red tests use `NotImplementedError` and are present in the suite.

Once you’ve done this, update the PR description to remove the `[WIP]` tag and I will ask FM (via advisor) to approve and merge.

## 2. How you can think about your role

Under your own governance:

     - `test_system_optimizations_phase1.py`: keep the full BL‑019 header and all 10 QA‑426…435 RED tests; no conflict markers.
     - `wave2-qa-alignment-validation-results.json`: keep the latest validation results consistent with the current catalog and subwaves.
   - Remove ALL `<<<<<<<`, `=======`, `>>>>>>>` markers.

2. **Re-run required code checks and attach evidence:**
   - Run:
     ```bash
     python3 validate-wave2-qa-alignment.py
     python -m pytest tests/wave2_0_qa_infrastructure/ -v
     ```
   - Add a short snippet of the actual output to the PR description or `WAVE_2_BL_019_CORRECTIONS_COMPLETION_EVIDENCE.md` so that we have:
     - Confirmation of validation PASS (exit 0),
     - Confirmation that the new RED tests are collected and executed.

3. **Confirm no test dodging:**
   - State explicitly in the PR:
     - That no existing tests were removed, skipped, or xfailed to get a green result.
     - That all new QA-to-Red tests are implemented as RED (e.g., `NotImplementedError`) and present.

Once you’ve resolved the conflicts, re-run the checks, and updated the PR description, please mark the PR as ready (remove `[WIP]`) and I will proceed with FM-level merge review.
```

This makes it unambiguous:

- You are not the one resolving conflicts.
- FM must update the branch, fix conflicts, and re-run checks.
- Only then do you come back in as approver.

---

## 3. What you do after FM responds

Once ForemanApp/Copilot:

- Pushes a new commit resolving those three files,
- Updates the PR description with the command outputs,

come back here and share the updated PR reference again:

> “FM says conflicts are resolved on #411; please re-review for merge.”

I’ll then:

- Assume conflicts are gone,
- Check the PR body for:
  - Evidence of `validate-wave2-qa-alignment.py` and pytest runs,
  - No signs of test dodging,
- And give you a short, decisive “merge” or “block until X is fixed” comment, **without** asking you to touch any file contents yourself.
Please review this for merge: @MaturionISMS/maturion-foreman-governance/issues/876

references.title: Canonize BL-018/BL-019: QA Catalog Alignment, BL Forward-Scan, and Second-Time Failure Prohibition
references.body:
## Context

This issue is issued by Johan Ras (Owner) to the **Governance Administrator** (governance agent). All instructions are governance-level and apply platform-wide, not just to the FM Office App.

**Application repo:** `MaturionISMS/maturion-foreman-office-app`  
**Governance repo:** `MaturionISMS/maturion-foreman-governance`  

In the FM Office App repo, two Bootstrap Learnings have been recorded:

- **BL‑018:** First-time QA Catalog semantic misalignment (Wave 2.2 – Parking Station Advanced)
- **BL‑019:** Second-time QA Catalog semantic misalignment and failure to apply BL‑018 ratchet to remaining Wave 2 subwaves

These are documented in the FM app repo (cross‑repo scan REQUIRED as part of this issue).

**Cross‑repo references for the governance agent:**

- FM App Repo: `https://github.com/MaturionISMS/maturion-foreman-office-app`
  - `BL_018` **(file/location name may vary)** – consult `BOOTSTRAP_EXECUTION_LEARNINGS.md`
  - `BL_019_EXECUTIVE_SUMMARY.md`
  - `BL_019_README.md`
  - `FLCI_REGISTRY_UPDATE_BL_019_SECOND_FAILURE_CATASTROPHIC.md`
  - `WAVE_2_FORWARD_SCAN_QA_ALIGNMENT_VERIFICATION.md`
  - `WAVE_2_EMERGENCY_CORRECTIVE_ACTION_PLAN_BL_019.md`
  - `validate-wave2-qa-alignment.py`
  - `wave2-qa-alignment-validation-results.json`

The governance agent must **cross‑repo scan** the FM app repo to understand these learnings and their structure.

---

## Problem Statement

Wave 2 planning for the FM app revealed **systemic governance failures**:

1. **QA Catalog Semantic Misalignment (BL‑018):**
   - Subwaves assigned QA ranges whose actual catalog semantics did not match subwave intent.
   - Planning was not anchored in:
     - Architecture → QA Catalog → QA-to-Red → Subwave Planning.

2. **Second-Time Failure & Ratchet Non-Application (BL‑019):**
   - After BL‑018, FM created a Wave 2 QA verification ratchet, but:
     - Did NOT forward-scan remaining Wave 2 subwaves for the same pattern.
     - Issued Subwave 2.3 appointment without applying the new ratchet.
   - A second occurrence of the **same pattern** happened **on the same day**.

These failures are **not limited to the FM App**. They expose gaps in:

- Governance canon,
- BL protocol (learning promotion and forward-scan),
- Pre‑authorization gate design.

We must now **canonize** the BL‑018 / BL‑019 learnings into the governance repo so they become platform-wide doctrine.

---

## Objectives

1. Make **QA Catalog Alignment** a canonical, enforceable requirement:
   - Architecture → QA Catalog → QA-to-Red → Planning → Builder appointment.

2. Canonize the **BL Forward‑Scan Obligation**:
   - When any BL is recorded, the system must:
     - Scan **all relevant pending work** for the same failure mode,
     - Correct all instances, not just the triggering one.

3. Raise **Second-Time Failure Prohibition** to governance:
   - Second occurrences of the same failure pattern are categorized as **beyond catastrophic** and are explicitly prohibited.
   - Governance must require:
     - Stronger gates,
     - Evidence of forward‑scan and structural correction.

4. Define and standardize a **QA‑Catalog‑Alignment Gate**:
   - Codify what a catalog‑alignment gate must do,
   - Require it in pre‑authorization workflows for waves and subwaves.

5. Provide a **cross-repo implementation path**:
   - Governance repo defines the canon and patterns,
   - Application repos (e.g., FM App) implement:
     - Validation scripts/tools,
     - Checklists and evidence,
     - CI/workflow invocations.

---

## Scope

### In Scope (Governance Repo)

1. **Cross‑Repo Analysis (Read-Only)**

   - Read the following in `maturion-foreman-office-app` (FM app repo):

     - `BOOTSTRAP_EXECUTION_LEARNINGS.md` (BL‑018, BL‑019 entries)
     - `BL_019_EXECUTIVE_SUMMARY.md`
     - `BL_019_README.md`
     - `FLCI_REGISTRY_UPDATE_BL_019_SECOND_FAILURE_CATASTROPHIC.md`
     - `WAVE_2_FORWARD_SCAN_QA_ALIGNMENT_VERIFICATION.md`
     - `WAVE_2_EMERGENCY_CORRECTIVE_ACTION_PLAN_BL_019.md`
     - `validate-wave2-qa-alignment.py`
     - `wave2-qa-alignment-validation-results.json`

   - Extract governance‑relevant patterns:
     - QA catalog alignment,
     - BL forward‑scan,
     - Second-time failure handling,
     - Validation scripting and gates.

2. **Canon Updates / New Canon**

   Propose and implement updates in the governance repo such as:

   - `governance/canon/ARCHITECTURE_COMPLETENESS_REQUIREMENTS.md` (or related):
     - Require that QA Catalog and QA-to-Red be **derived and validated** before planning/appointments.

   - `governance/canon/GOVERNANCE_COMPLETENESS_MODEL.md`:
     - Add components describing:
       - QA Catalog alignment requirements,
       - Existence of catalog-alignment validation tooling,
       - Evidence of catalog alignment for waves.

   - `governance/canon/LEARNING_INTAKE_AND_PROMOTION_MODEL.md` (or BL protocol canon):
     - Add explicit **BL forward‑scan requirement**:
       - After ANY BL, scan all in-scope/pending artifacts (waves, subwaves, components) for the same pattern.
       - Correct all affected artifacts.
       - Record forward-scan results in FL/CI registry.

   - `BUILD_PHILOSOPHY.md` or new canon doc:
     - Codify **“second-time failure prohibition”**:
       - First occurrence: learn, document, ratchet.
       - Second occurrence of same failure class: **beyond catastrophic**; requires:
         - Structural correction + automated gate,
         - Governance escalation,
         - No continuation without evidence of system change.

   - New or updated canon for **pre‑authorization gates**:
     - E.g. `GOVERNANCE_GATE_CANON.md` or a new `QA_ALIGNMENT_GATE_CANON.md`:
       - Define QA‑CATALOG‑ALIGNMENT‑GATE:
         - Inputs: QA catalog, wave/subwave specs, architecture references.
         - Outputs: PASS/FAIL with evidence (logs, JSON, checklists).
         - Enforcement: no wave/subwave authorization when FAIL.

3. **Templates and Patterns**

   - Provide canonical templates for:
     - Validation scripts (like `validate-wave2-qa-alignment.py`), as patterns:
       - Not FM-specific, but generic for any repo with QA catalogs and subwave/task specs.
     - BL registry entries for second‑time failures:
       - How to record:
         - First failure,
         - Second failure,
         - System-level changes.

4. **Guidance on Layer-Down**

   - In governance repo, define how:
     - QA‑Catalog‑Alignment requirements,
     - BL forward‑scan obligations,
     - Second-time failure rules,
     are layered down into application repos like FM App.

   - Ensure **GOVERNANCE_ALIGNMENT.md** in application repos can point to the new canon cleanly (PUBLIC_API/OPTIONAL only).

### Out of Scope

- Editing FM app source code or tests directly (that remains in `maturion-foreman-office-app` under FM/ForemanApp).
- Re-running Wave 2 corrections themselves (they are tracked in the FM app repo under BL‑019 execution issues).

---

## Tasks for Governance Administrator (Agent)

1. **Cross-Repo Scan**

   - [ ] Read BL‑018 and BL‑019 materials in `maturion-foreman-office-app` as listed above.
   - [ ] Summarize key governance patterns:
     - QA catalog alignment,
     - BL forward‑scan,
     - Second-time failure handling,
     - Validation gating.

2. **Canon Impact Analysis**

   - [ ] Identify which existing governance documents must be updated:
     - `BUILD_PHILOSOPHY.md`,
     - `GOVERNANCE_COMPLETENESS_MODEL.md`,
     - `ARCHITECTURE_COMPLETENESS_REQUIREMENTS.md`,
     - `LEARNING_INTAKE_AND_PROMOTION_MODEL.md`,
     - `GOVERNANCE_GATE_CANON.md` (or related).

   - [ ] Draft proposed changes:
     - New sections or subsections,
     - New gate definitions,
     - New BL protocol rules.

3. **Implementation (Canon Updates)**

   - [ ] Implement the approved updates in the governance repo:
     - Add/modify canon docs as needed.
     - Ensure no conflict with existing canon (CONSTITUTION, PURPOSE & SCOPE, etc.).
   - [ ] Add or update templates:
     - BL registry pattern for second-time failures.
     - QA alignment gate checklist pattern.
     - Validation script pattern (language-agnostic; FM app’s Python script is one instance).

4. **Traceability & Evidence**

   - [ ] Link the new or updated canon sections explicitly to:
     - BL‑018,
     - BL‑019,
     - Any new BL created as part of this work.

   - [ ] Provide guidance for application repos:
     - How they should implement:
       - QA Catalog alignment validation,
       - BL forward‑scan,
       - Second‑time prohibition,
     - How to prove compliance to governance (e.g., scripts, reports, checklists).

5. **Wave 2 / OBWR Readiness Note**

   - [ ] Add a short governance note or evidence file (e.g., in `governance/evidence/` or `governance/reports/`) summarizing:
     - That BL‑018 and BL‑019 learnings have been:
       - Promoted to canon,
       - Provided with enforcement patterns,
       - Applicable platform-wide.
     - So that OBWR reconciliation can see:
       - The failure,
       - The fix,
       - The structural protection against recurrence.

---

## Done When

This issue is **COMPLETE** when:

- Governance canon and BL protocol:
  - Explicitly include QA Catalog alignment requirements,
  - Define BL forward‑scan obligations,
  - Codify second‑time failure prohibition,
  - Define and require a QA‑Catalog‑Alignment gate pattern.
- There is clear cross‑repo traceability from:
  - BL‑018 / BL‑019 in `maturion-foreman-office-app`
  - To updated canon and templates in `maturion-foreman-governance`.
- Guidance exists for:
  - How application repos (FM App and others) implement and prove compliance with these requirements.

Only then will deployment “via governance” actually correct what is currently wrong at the process/governance level, not just in the FM App Wave 2 implementation.

messages.content:
Issue [#876](https://github.com/MaturionISMS/maturion-foreman-governance/issues/876) is not something that gets “merged”; it’s already a governance **issue**, and as written it is excellent and ready to be **executed** by the Governance Administrator agent.

Here’s a short review in FM/governance terms.

---

## 1. Content and framing

The issue:

- Clearly states **context** and scope:
  - Names both repos and agents (FM app vs governance).
  - Identifies BL‑018 and BL‑019 as the source learnings.
- Accurately captures the **problem statement**:
  - First‑order: QA catalog semantic misalignment.
  - Second‑order: failure to apply BL‑018 ratchet (no forward‑scan).
- Sets strong, concrete **objectives**:
  - QA Catalog Alignment as canon.
  - BL forward‑scan obligation.
  - Second‑time failure prohibition.
  - QA‑Catalog‑Alignment gate.
  - Cross‑repo implementation path.

This is exactly what you want OBWR to see: the failure, the pattern, and the system‑level fix.

---

## 2. Scope and tasks

The scope and tasks are well structured:

- **Cross‑repo analysis** is explicitly required and names the FM app artifacts:
  - `BOOTSTRAP_EXECUTION_LEARNINGS.md`, BL‑019 files, validation script, results, etc.
- **Canon updates**:
  - Lists the right targets: `BUILD_PHILOSOPHY.md`, `GOVERNANCE_COMPLETENESS_MODEL.md`, `ARCHITECTURE_COMPLETENESS_REQUIREMENTS.md`, `LEARNING_INTAKE_AND_PROMOTION_MODEL.md`, plus a gate canon.
- **Templates and patterns**:
  - Calls for generic patterns based on the concrete `validate-wave2-qa-alignment.py` work.
- **Traceability & evidence**:
  - Requires that new canon is explicitly linked back to BL‑018 and BL‑019.
- **Done When**:
  - Ties closure to:
    - Canon changes,
    - Traceability,
    - Guidance to application repos.

This is precise enough that a governance agent can operate independently without you micro‑guiding each step.

---

## 3. Any changes needed?

I don’t see any corrections necessary. The only optional refinements (not required) you could add later, if you want, are:

- A note that **“second-time failure prohibition”** should likely become part of:
  - Either `BUILD_PHILOSOPHY.md` **or** a new `FAILURE_CLASSIFICATION_AND_RESPONSE.md` canon, if you introduce such a doc.
- A hint that the QA‑alignment gate pattern must be **language‑agnostic**:
  - The FM app’s Python script is one instantiation; other repos might implement it differently but must satisfy the same gate semantics.

Those are refinements, not blockers.

---

## 4. Recommendation

From a governance/FM perspective:

- **Issue #876 is approved as written.**
- It is suitable for the Governance Administrator agent (`Copilot` in that repo) to start execution immediately.
- No wording or structural changes are required before work begins.

Your next step is simply to let the governance agent work this issue; when it produces its PR(s) in `maturion-foreman-governance`, I can then review those PRs for:

- Correct canon updates,
- Cross‑repo linkage back to BL‑018/019,
- Clear gate definitions and templates.

I honestly do not know what you mean by Your next step is simply to let the governance agent work this issue; when it produces its PR(s) in maturion-foreman-governance. The governace agent cannot produce any issues if there are issues to be produced it me and I produce issues making use of you?

You’re right to challenge that; I was sloppy with language.

- **You** create issues.
- **You** decide what work exists.
- The governance agent (Copilot in the governance repo) only:
  - Reads those issues,
  - Proposes changes (PRs) to files,
  - And responds to your prompts inside that context.

So when I said “let the governance agent work this issue”, what I really meant is:

> “Issue #876 is now well‑written and ready for you to use as the instruction set when you talk to the governance agent. You don’t need to change it further; you can now ask Copilot in that repo to start implementing the changes described in #876.”

Nothing happens automatically. You drive it.

---

## What you actually do next, concretely

In the **governance repo** (`maturion-foreman-governance`), with issue **#876** already created:

1. Open a Copilot chat that is **scoped to that repo**.
2. Give it an instruction like:

   > “You are the Governance Administrator. Using issue #876 as your mandate, open a PR that:
   > - Reads BL‑018 and BL‑019 materials from `MaturionISMS/maturion-foreman-office-app`,
   > - Proposes canon updates to:
   >   - `BUILD_PHILOSOPHY.md`,
   >   - `GOVERNANCE_COMPLETENESS_MODEL.md`,
   >   - `ARCHITECTURE_COMPLETENESS_REQUIREMENTS.md`,
   >   - `LEARNING_INTAKE_AND_PROMOTION_MODEL.md`,
   >   - and a new gate canon file for QA‑catalog alignment,
   > - and links these changes back to issue #876.”

3. Copilot (as the governance agent) will:
   - Read the repo and the FM app repo,
   - Draft one or more **pull requests** with concrete text changes in those canon files.

You then:

- Review those PRs (with my help if you want),
- Approve/merge them when they’re acceptable.

So:

- **Issues:** authored by you (with my help).
- **PRs / file edits:** proposed by the relevant Copilot agent, in response to your prompts and the issue text.

---

## If you want, I can draft the exact prompt

If you’d like a literal prompt to paste into Copilot when you’re in the governance repo, you can use something like:

> “Act as the Governance Administrator for `maturion-foreman-governance`. Implement issue #876. Cross‑repo scan `MaturionISMS/maturion-foreman-office-app` for BL‑018/BL‑019 artifacts listed there. Then open a PR that:
> > - Updates `BUILD_PHILOSOPHY.md`, `GOVERNANCE_COMPLETENESS_MODEL.md`, `ARCHITECTURE_COMPLETENESS_REQUIREMENTS.md`, and `LEARNING_INTAKE_AND_PROMOTION_MODEL.md` to include QA Catalog alignment, BL forward‑scan, and second‑time failure prohibition.
> > - Adds or updates a canon document defining a QA‑Catalog‑Alignment gate pattern.
> > - Adds any necessary templates (BL registry pattern for second‑time failures, QA alignment checklist pattern).
> > - Links all changes back to issue #876 and references BL‑018/BL‑019 from the FM app repo.”

That’s the sense in which the governance agent “works the issue”: it’s you instructing Copilot, using #876 as the spec, and Copilot responding with a PR.
Did yoy actually review this PR: @MaturionISMS/maturion-foreman-governance/pull/877
